questions.question:
Question 1: A man is referred for fever and agitation for the past 4 days. Examination reveals a 
disoriented man who is unable to swallow water due to involuntary inspiratory muscle 
spasms of the pharynx. He had been bitten by a dog 3 months ago but was not treated. What 
genus does the causative organism of this condition belong to?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario with hydrophobia and a history of an untreated dog bite is highly suggestive 
of rabies. The causative virus belongs to the genus Lyssavirus. Rabies virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Rhabdoviridae. This family has 3 genera: • Lyssavirus • Vesiculovirus • Ephemerovirus

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following does not lead to the transmission of rabies to humans?

options.a: Nibbling by an infected animal on abraded skin
options.c: Direct contact of infected saliva with the mucosa
options.d: Ingestion of raw meat of infected animal

questions.explanation:
Ingestion of the raw meat of the infected animal does not lead to the transmission of rabies. 285 
Sold by @itachibot Mammals like dogs and bats are important animal sources. The important modes of transmission 
of rabies are as follows: • Scratches or deep bites • Exposure of infected saliva to intact mucosa or fresh skin wounds Human–to–human transmission through bites has never been confirmed.

questions.question:
Question 4: You have witnessed your neighbor being bitten by a rabid dog. You should advise him to wash 
the wound with soap and water for a minimum of: 279 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Following dog bites, the bite wound should be washed with soap under running tap water for 15 
minutes. Local treatment of the bite wound is essential for the prevention of rabies and can reduce the 
infection rate by up to 80%. The following steps must be followed: • Cleansing: Washing under running water with soap or irrigation with a catheter in case of deep 
wounds • Chemical agent: Alcohol or tincture /0.01% aqueous solution of iodine or povidone-iodine is 
effective for inactivation of residual virus • Suturing: Must be done only following 24-48 hours if necessary, under the cover of rabies 
immunoglobulin locally and minimal stitches • Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures when indicated

questions.question:
Question 5: A worker at a veterinary hospital has just received the 1st dose of rabies vaccine as a 
pre-exposure prophylactic measure. When should he return for the remaining doses?
questions.explanation:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies consists of 3 doses to be given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 
28. They are given intramuscularly or intradermally in the deltoid area of the arm. High-risk groups like laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and 
travelers to endemic regions are candidates for pre-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 7-year-old boy was bitten by a suspected rabid dog . On examination, there are minor 
scratches and abrasions without bleeding. Which of the following is true about the category 
and management of the wound?

options.a: Category II - Local treatment of wound with povidone and follow up
options.b: Category III - Local treatment of wound and give ARV and antibiotics
options.c: Category II - Local treatment of wound and give ARV
options.d: Category III - Give ARV and anti-rabies immunoglobulin

questions.explanation:
Minor scratches and abrasions without bleeding are classified under category II wounds. Category 
II wounds are managed by immediate local treatment of wound and vaccination (ARV). Antibiotics are not required in case of minor scratches and abrasions.

questions.question:
Question 7: A public health worker was brought with multiple transdermal dog bites. He tells you that he 
had received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago. What is the next best step in 
management?

options.c: Wound washing and ARV with half dose of RIG
options.d: Wound treatment and ARV; RIG is not required

questions.explanation:
This given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple transdermal dog bites would be categorised 
under category III. As the patient received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago, his line of 286 
Sold by @itachibot management includes the following: • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes and application of antiseptic • Anti-rabies vaccine 2 doses on day 0 and day 3, with either intradermal vaccine(0.1ml, 1 site) or 
intramuscular vaccine(1 vial, 1site). There is no requirement for Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), if previous pre-exposure prophylaxis 
or post exposure prophylaxis documentation is available. If documentation of PEP or PrEP is 
unavailable, patient should be treated as fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.question:
Question 8: An■ 8-year-old child was brought with an unprovoked dog bite. Which of the following 
measures should be taken?

options.a: Withhold the vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
options.b: Give half the dose of the vaccine

questions.explanation:
This child should be given immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) by administering a cell 
culture-derived vaccine to reduce the chances of getting rabies.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 5-year-old boy had received a full course rabies vaccine taken in December 2018. His pet 
dog which has been fully vaccinated now (November 2019) bit him on the toe. Bleeding was 
present at the site of the bite. What would be the line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
This boy should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has received a prior course of 
post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago. Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure 
prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows: • Category I: Wound treatment only • Category II/ III: • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic • Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) on 
days 0 and 3. *Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play a 
significant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the incubation period of yellow fever?
questions.explanation: The incubation period of yellow fever is 3–6 days.

questions.question:
Question 11: According to the International Health Regulations, an Aedes aegypti index of which of the 
following must be maintained to achieve zero risk of spread of yellow fever?
questions.explanation:
The Aedes aegypti index should be < 1% in endemic areas to achieve zero risk of spread of 
yellow fever. The Aedes aegypti index is a type of house index. It refers to the percentage of houses and 
premises in a limited well-defined area with actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae. 287 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel 
regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination 
is she eligible to travel?
questions.explanation:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow 
fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity. The 17D vaccine for yellow fever is given subcutaneously. Unvaccinated people are required to 
remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the yellow fever reference center in India?
questions.explanation: The reference centers for yellow fever in India are as follows: • Central Research Institute, Kasauli • National Institute of Virology, Pune

questions.question:
Question 14: An outbreak of Kyasanur forest disease occurred among a group of forest officers in 
Karnataka. Which of the following vectors should be targeted to prevent the further spread of 
the disease?
questions.explanation:
Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is transmitted by the bite of infective hard ticks of Haemaphysalis 
species. Hence, control of ticks must be done to prevent spread of the disease. KFD is a hemorrhagic febrile disease caused by a flavivirus. Man is an incidental dead-end host in 
the life cycle of the vector (hard tick). Small mammals like rodents and squirrels are the reservoirs 
while monkeys serve as the amplifier hosts. KFD is endemic in 4 districts of Karnataka (Shimoga, 
North Kannada, South Kannada, Chikmagalur). The incubation period is between 3 to 8 days. The disease presents with sudden onset of fever, 
headache, myalgia. In severe cases, gastrointestinal disturbances and hemorrhages from the nose, 
gums, stomach, and intestine may occur. The case fatality rate is 5 to 10%.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route?
questions.explanation:
Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basic 
cycles of transmission are: (a) Pig  Mosquito  Pig (b) Bird  Mosquito  Bird Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes. 288 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which following is false about Japanese encephalitis?

options.a: Man is the incidental dead-end host
options.b: Culicines act as vectors for this condition
options.d: It is caused by a group B arbovirus

questions.explanation:
The incubation period of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in man following a mosquito bite is 5-15 days. JE is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus). It is transmitted by 
Culex (culicine) mosquitoes mainly C.tritaeniorhynchus and C.vishnui. Ardeid birds (herons) are 
the reservoirs while pigs are the amplifier hosts. Man is an incidental dead-end host. Man-to-man 
transmission has not been recorded.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is true about Japanese encephalitis?

options.a: SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is commonly used
options.b: Diagnosis is confirmed by CSF culture
options.c: Patients usually recover without any sequelae

questions.explanation:
SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is used for the prevention of Japanese encephalitis (JE). Japanese encephalitis (JE) is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus 
(Flavivirus) and transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. Most individuals develop subclinical infection. The course of disease in man divided into 3 stages: • Prodromal stage - fever, headache, gastrointestinal disturbances, lethargy, and malaise • Acute encephalitic stage - high-grade fever, nuchal rigidity, convulsions, signs of raised 
intracranial pressure, paralysis, altered sensorium • Late-stage and sequelae - neurological or psychiatric sequelae seen in up to 50% of survivors Diagnosis is serological, using blood or CSF samples. The virus rarely grows in culture. The case 
fatality rate varies between 20-40%. There are 3 types of JE vaccines available: • Nakayama or Beijing strain - purified inactivated vaccine • Beijing P-3 strain - inactivated vaccine • SA-14-14-2 - live attenuated vaccine Note: Killed JE vaccines (Inactivated SA 14-14-2 cell culture-derived and inactivated Vero cell 
culture-derived) are gradually replacing live attenuated vaccines. According to the national 
immunisation schedule, both live attenuated, killed-inactivated vaccines are now used for 
vaccination against the JE virus.

questions.question:
Question 18: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below? 283 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus. Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus. It is 
a zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human 
transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family. The clinical manifestations include asymptomatic subclinical infection, acute respiratory 
infection, and fatal encephalitis. There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or 
animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care. Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases. 289
